div.note: As it grew more and more difficult to address the dire needs created by the situation, the Council of the Decurioni resolved, on the fourth of May, to appeal to the Governor for help.

On the twenty-second, two of its members were sent to the army camp below Casale to report the straits and troubles of the city: the enormous expenses, the empty coffers, the future years’ revenue already committed, and the current taxes unpaid, due to the widespread misery whose many causes included, primarily, the squandering of resources on the army. They were to request that the Royal Treasury bear the costs of the plague, as mandated by law and unbroken custom, and by special decree of Emperor Charles V. During the plague of 1576, the Governor of Milan, the Marquis of Ayamonte, had not only suspended all government taxes, but he had also given the city a subsidy of forty thousand scudi from the treasury. The Council requested four things in particular: the suspension of taxes, as per the previous outbreak; financing from the treasury; a dispatch from the Governor to the King detailing the misery in the city and in the province; and a halt to any new military garrisons, since the area was already devastated by the existing ones.

In response, the Governor sent his condolences along with words of encouragement: He regretted that he could not be in the city to help with the relief effort, but hoped, nonetheless, that the zeal of the council would compensate for everything, because now was the time to spend unstintingly, and to make every possible effort.
As to their requests, proueeré en el mejor modo que el tiempo y necesidades presentes permitieren—I shall do my best to see to them as the current time and needs allow.
At the bottom of his letter was a scribble standing in for his name, Ambrogio Spinola, the signature every bit as clear as his promises.

Grand Chancellor Ferrer responded that the council had read the Governor’s missive con gran desconsuelo—with heavy hearts. Other delegations went back and forth, with more questions and answers, but I have found no evidence that less ambiguous conclusions were reached.

Some time later, at the height of the plague, the Governor sent an official letter to Ferrer, deputizing him to take charge of the outbreak, since he himself, as he wrote, was too occupied with the war: a war that, by the way, after at least one million people had died from the plague (not counting the soldiers), throughout northern Italy, from Lombardy to the Venetian territories, Piedmont, Tuscany, and part of Romagna; and after the taking and barbaric sack of Mantua, had ended with everyone recognizing Nevers as the new Duke of Mantua, when the whole purpose of the war had been to keep him out of Italy.

Nevers was obliged, however, to cede to the Duke of Savoy a part of Montferrat (which provided a measly income of fifteen thousand scudi), and to the Duke of Guastalla, Ferrante, other lands (for an income of six thousand scudi); not to mention a separate confidential pact, by which the Duke of Savoy ceded Pinerolo to France, in a treaty that was executed sometime later, under other pretexts, and through deception.

The Decurioni also adopted another resolution: to ask the Cardinal-Archbishop for a solemn procession through the city of the body of San Carlo, who had administered heroically to the needs of the people during the previous plague.
The good prelate refused, for several reasons.
He disliked this trust in an arbitrary measure, and feared that, if it failed to produce results (which he also feared), then that trust would give way to rioting.

Moreover, he feared that, if these anointers really did exist, the procession would be an occasion all too fitting for the crime. And if they did not, the congregation of so many people would only serve to further spread the epidemic: a much more real danger (“Si unguenta scelerata et unctores in urbe essent…Si non essent…Certiusque adeo malum” [Ripamonti, 185]).
Because in the meantime, the underlying suspicion of unguents had been revived and was raging more widely and furiously than before.
Once again, the walls and doors of public buildings, as well as the doorways and door knockers of private homes had been seen, or this time supposedly seen, swabbed with an unguent.
The news of these discoveries flew from mouth to mouth, and hearing about them had the same effect as seeing them, as often happens in times of high anxiety.

People willingly embraced these rumors as they became more distressed by the disease’s presence, and irritated by its stubborn threat. For anger is quick to punish, and as a wise man accurately observed, it would rather blame troubles on human misconduct, against which it can exact revenge, than recognize a cause against which it can only resign itself.
A refined poison, instantaneous and highly penetrating: These words were used to explain the virulence of the disease, as well as its most obscure and disordered symptoms.
The poison was said to be concocted from the worst of every foul and atrocious thing that wild and twisted imaginations could invent: toads, snakes, saliva, even the flesh of plague victims.
Some said it was witchcraft, which caused every symptom, weakened every objection, and overcame every obstacle.

If no symptoms appeared immediately after the first sighting of the unguents, the reason was clear: Amateur poisoners must have failed in their first attempt. But now the art had been perfected, and the perpetrators were hell-bent on carrying out their plan.

Anyone who had argued that it was a prank, or denied the existence of a plot, was dismissed as blind or obstinate, or even suspected of trying to conceal the truth from the public, namely, that he himself was an accomplice, an anointer. That word soon became common, solemn, tremendous.
The fervent belief in anointers made their discovery inevitable: All eyes were alert, any act could prove suspicious.
And suspicion led easily to certainty, and certainty to fury.

Ripamonti sets forth two examples as proof, and advises the reader that he did not select them because they were the most atrocious examples of what had become a daily occurrence, but because he had unfortunately been an eyewitness to both.
At the Church of San Antonio, on some feast day or another, a man in his late eighties wanted to sit down after having prayed for a time on his knees, so he dusted off the pew with his cloak.
“That old man is anointing the pews!” came the cry from some women who had witnessed his gesture.

The other churchgoers jumped on top of him (in church, of all places!). They grabbed him by his white hair, and pummeled him with their fists and feet. They pushed and pulled him outside, and if they didn’t finish him off there, it was only so they could haul him, half-dead, to the prison, to the judges, to the torture chambers. “I saw him while they were dragging him out like that,” writes Ripamonti, “and I did not hear another word about what happened to him. I am quite sure he could not have survived more than a few more minutes.”
The other case (on the following day) was equally strange but not equally fatal.

Three young French friends, a writer, a painter, and a craftsman, were in Italy to study antiquities and seek opportunities to make money. They approached I don’t know which external wall of the Duomo, and were observing it attentively.

A man walking by saw them and stopped. He gestured to someone else, and others arrived on the scene. A crowd gathered to watch and keep an eye on them, since their clothing, hairstyles, and shoulder bags gave them away as foreigners, and what’s worse, as Frenchmen.
The young men reached out their hands to touch the wall, perhaps to verify if it was marble.
That was all it took.
They were surrounded, grabbed, beaten, and then pushed and shoved to the prison.
Luckily the courthouse was not far from the Duomo, and even more luckily, they were found innocent and released.
Nor did such things happen only in the city. Frenzy had propagated like the disease.

The wayfarer who happened to encounter some peasants off the main road, and lingered to look around, or to lie down to rest; the stranger who seemed to have something odd, something suspicious in his face, in his clothing: They were both anointers. At the cry of “anointers,” at the shout of a child, the drumbeat began and people came running. The hapless soul was either pelted with stones, or grabbed and hauled off to prison by the mob.
This even happened to Ripamonti.
And prison, at least, was a temporary safe haven.
But the Decurioni, undeterred by the wise Cardinal’s refusal, and with the loud backing of public opinion, continued to pressure him to hold the procession.

Federigo resisted for a while longer, trying to make them understand. This was as much wisdom as one man could muster against the forces of his times and the insistence of the majority, against public opinion, with its confused idea of danger, contradicted and unsupported by the evidence we know today. It was only a matter of time before his good arguments succumbed to the bad convictions of others.
Whether or not a weak will played a part in his concession is a mystery of the human heart.

Of course, if there is ever a case that the full blame can be put on the intellect, while the conscience is excused, it is when we are dealing with one of those (very) few men who seem to have resolutely obeyed their conscious, rather than their earthly interests, their whole life long.

So after repeated urgings, the Cardinal finally gave in, not just to the procession, but also to the desires, and the demands, to display the casket holding the relics of San Carlo for eight days on the main altar of the Duomo.
I have found no evidence that the Tribunal of Health, or other government bodies, raised protests or objections of any kind.
The tribunal merely ordered that a few precautions be taken that, while doing nothing to protect against the danger, did indicate its fears.

Stricter regulations on people entering the city were adopted and in order to guarantee that they were executed, the gates were kept closed. The doors of quarantined houses were nailed shut to keep the infected and the suspected away from the crowd as much as possible. If we can believe the word of one writer, not to mention a writer of that period, there were about five hundred such houses.
Three days were spent in preparations. On the appointed date, the eleventh of June, the procession started out from the Duomo at dawn.
A long line of people, mostly women, walked in front, their faces covered by large heavy veils. Many of them were barefoot and dressed in sackcloth.

Next came the guilds, preceded by their flags, and the confraternities, in habits of various styles and colors. After them were the religious orders, then the lay priests, each wearing the insignia appropriate to his rank and holding a candle or torch.

In the center, amid the brightness of many candles together and the loud sound of the singing, beneath an elaborate canopy, the crystal casket advanced, borne by four luxuriously dressed clergymen who rotated periodically.

Through the crystal you could see the venerated body, dressed in splendid pontifical robes, with a miter on its skull. In its decayed and mutilated form, one could still make out vestiges of San Carlo’s former appearance, as depicted in his portraits, and as he was remembered by those who had seen and revered him when he was alive.

Behind the mortal remains of the late pastor (according to Ripamonti, our main source for this description), and close to him in merit, family, and rank, and on this day, also in person, came Archbishop Federigo.

The rest of the clergy were next, followed by the magistrates in their most ceremonious garments. Then the nobility, some dressed in finery, as if for a solemn religious ceremony, while others were dressed in mourning, either barefoot or hooded, with masks pulled over their faces as a sign of penance. Everyone held procession candles.
An assortment of common people brought up the tail end of the procession.

The entire route was decorated as if for a festival. The rich had laid out their most precious belongings. The façades of the more humble homes had been decorated by their wealthier neighbors or at public expense. Banners or leafy garlands were strung from the buildings. Everywhere one looked there were paintings, inscriptions, coats of arms. Vases, antiquities, and other rarities were put out for display on the windowsills. Illumination everywhere.
Those who were quarantined watched the procession from their windows and followed it with their prayers.

The side streets were silent and deserted, except for people who were listening, also from the windows, to the wandering buzz of the crowd. Others, including nuns, had climbed up to their roofs, hoping to catch a glimpse of the casket, of the procession, of anything at all, from a distance.

The procession passed through every neighborhood of the city. At each intersection, or rather little piazza—which in those days were called carrobi (only one remains today)—where the main roads fed into the neighborhoods, the procession would come to a stop, and they’d lay the casket at the foot of a cross. San Carlo had ordered these crosses—some of which are still standing today—placed at each intersection during the previous plague.

In this manner the procession ended up back at the Duomo sometime after midday. Lo and behold, while many believed confidently and with fanatical certainty that the procession would end the plague, the death toll went up the next day, in every social class and in every part of the city. It rose so suddenly and so steeply that no one could mistake the cause, or the occasion, for anything other than the procession itself.

But, oh, the incredible deadly power of a common prejudice! The assembly of so many people, and for so long, was not blamed. Nor was the infinite multiplication of casual contacts. The blame was laid squarely on the ease with which the anointers had been able to carry out their evil plan on a large scale.
The rumor was that they had mingled with the crowd, infecting as many people as possible with their unguent.

But that did not seem an adequate or appropriate explanation for the death of so many people, across every social class. Apparently not even the eyes most keen on identifying suspicious behavior (and misinterpreting it) had caught a glimpse of unguent smears or stains of any kind on the walls or anywhere else. So to explain this turn of events, they had to fall back on the other venerable myth of poisonous malignant powders that the scientific community of Europe believed in those days. Rumor had it that these powders had been sprinkled along the streets and especially at the places where the procession stopped, thus sticking to the hems of clothing and to the bare feet of those who had walked in the crowd that day.

“Hence on the same day of the procession, piety could be seen clashing with evil, perfidy with honesty, and loss with gain,” according to one contemporary writer. In truth, it was feeble human intellect clashing with its own delusions.

From that day, the fury of the contagion raged out of control. In no time hardly a single house was left untouched. In no time the population of the lazaretto, according to Somaglia, rose from two thousand to twelve thousand. According to almost everyone, it later reached as high as sixteen thousand.
On the fourth of July, as I discovered in another letter from the Tribunal of Health to the Governor, the mortality rate exceeded more than five hundred people a day.
According to the most common statistic, the plague claimed twelve or fifteen hundred lives a day at its peak, or, if we are to believe Tadino, more than thirty-five hundred.
Tadino also states that, “Through the inquiries made after the plague,” the population of Milan was found to have declined by more than 64,000 souls, where it had once exceeded 250,000.
According to Ripamonti, the previous population had stood at only 200,000 and the death toll recorded by the vital statistics office was 140,000, apart from those who could not be counted.
Other historians give higher or lower totals, but with little support for their claims.
Imagine the difficulty in which the Decurioni now found themselves. It was their duty to provide for the public needs and to remedy whatever they could during such a disaster.
Every day they had to replace and replenish the ranks of various types of civil servants: monatti, apparitori, and commissioners.

The monatti were responsible for the most difficult and dangerous jobs during the plague: removing the dead bodies from the homes, streets, and lazaretto; carting them away to the common grave and burying them; transporting or accompanying the sick to the lazaretto and taking charge of their care; and burning or disinfecting infected or suspicious items.

Ripamonti claims that the name monatto is derived from the Greek monos (alone). In a description of the previous plague, Gaspare Bugatti says it came from the Latin monere (to admonish), though at the same time he wonders, more plausibly, whether it is actually a German word, since these men had been recruited mainly from Switzerland and the Grisons.

So it would not be too far-fetched, in fact, to think it was a truncated form of the word monatlich (monthly), since they were hired on a month-to-month basis, given the uncertainty over how long the job might last.
The apparitori were assigned to walk ahead of the carts bearing the dead, ringing a bell to warn the pedestrians to keep their distance.
The commissioners were in charge of both, and reported directly to the Tribunal of Health.
The lazaretto needed to have doctors, surgeons, medicine, food, and all the equipment of an infirmary ready at all times. New lodgings had to be found and prepared for the afflicted arriving daily.

Wood and straw huts were quickly erected in the yard of the lazaretto for this purpose. A new lazaretto, able to accommodate four thousand people, was built consisting entirely of huts, surrounded by a simple fence.
Since this was still not enough, two more were commissioned, and construction began, but had to be canceled due to a shortage of every type of building material.
Supplies, personnel, and energy diminished at the same pace as the need grew.

Not only was execution always lagging behind plans and orders; not only were many sadly recognized needs barely provided for, even in the form of lip service; but such an extreme of impotence and despair was reached that many of the most piteous and urgent cases were not provided for at all.

A great many infants whose mothers had died from the plague, for example, would themselves die from abandonment. The Tribunal of Health proposed that a shelter be established for orphans and destitute expectant mothers, since something had to be done for them, but nothing ever was.

“One still had to pity, nevertheless,” writes Tadino, “the Decurioni of the city, who were afflicted, harassed and mistreated by unruly and disrespectful soldiers; as well as, to a much lesser extent, by other parts of the unhappy Duchy, since neither help nor provisions were forthcoming from the Governor, who would only say that it was wartime, and the troops had to be well cared for” (117).
That’s how important it was considered to take Casale!
Victory was held in the highest esteem, no matter the cause or purpose of the conflict.

At the same time, since the large but single ditch that had been dug near the lazaretto was filled to capacity with cadavers, growing numbers of bodies lay unburied in the lazaretto and throughout the city. The magistrates, after searching in vain for new laborers to do the grim task of moving the bodies, had to admit that they didn’t know where else to turn.
Who knows how it would have ended if exceptional relief did not arrive?

In despair, the President of the Tribunal of Health, with tears in his eyes, appealed to the two good friars who were in charge of the lazaretto. Padre Michele promised he would help clear the city of bodies within four days, and what’s more, within eight days he would dig enough new common graves not only to satisfy the present need, but also to handle the worst projections for the future.

Along with a fellow friar and members of the tribunal offered by the President, he went outside the city to recruit peasants. He was able to enlist about two hundred men to dig three enormous ditches, thanks to the authority of the tribunal, as well as the authority of his habit and his words. He then sent the monatti from the lazaretto to collect the dead, and thus fulfilled his promise by the agreed date.
At one point, the lazaretto was left without doctors. Some were rustled up, through offers of good pay and perquisites, but far fewer than needed, and only after difficulties and delays.

Food supplies often ran so low that there were fears of death by starvation. More than once, when the necessary resources were nowhere to be found, generous donations arrived unexpectedly from anonymous parties just in time. So while many were in constant fear for their own well-being, numb and indifferent to the needs of others, there were still souls inclined to charity or whose charitable impulses were awakened by the loss of all earthly delights. Though many in charge of supervising and provisioning had died or departed, there were still men, healthy in body and steadfast in courage, who remained on the job. And there were still others, moved by pity, who took on and ably shouldered duties that were not theirs by profession.
Those most generous, ready, and constantly devoted to the difficult needs of this moment, however, were the clergy.

At the lazarettos and in the city, their assistance never faltered. Wherever there was suffering, they were present. They could always be seen moving about and administering care to the sick and dying, even if they were sick and dying themselves. They brought relief not only to the spirit but also to the body, as best they could. They provided every service that the circumstances demanded of them.
In the city alone, more than sixty priests died from the epidemic: about eight out of every nine.
As one would expect, Cardinal Federigo provided an encouraging example for all.

After almost his entire household had died, relatives, senior magistrates, and the rulers of neighboring states begged him to escape from danger and seek refuge in the countryside. He rejected their advice and resisted their pressure in the same spirit with which he wrote to his priests: “Be prepared to shuffle off this mortal coil rather than forsake this family, these children, of ours: go forth to the plague with love in your heart, as you would toward a reward, toward a life, so long as there is a single soul that can be won for Christ” (Ripamonti, 164).

He followed precautions unless they interfered with his duties, and he instructed his fellow clergymen to do the same. At the same time, he ignored and did not seem to notice dangers he might face on his missions of mercy.

He was forever praising and regulating the zeal of the clergy, to encourage those whose energy was flagging, and sending them to replace other priests who had died. He wanted the door to be kept open to anyone who needed him.

He visited the lazarettos to console the sick and inspire their attendants. He rushed about the city, bringing relief to the poor souls quarantined in their homes, stopping by their doors and below their windows to hear their complaints and, in exchange, offering a few words of consolation and encouragement.
He spared no efforts, in other words, and lived in the heart of the plague. And in the end, no one was more surprised than he to have come out of it unharmed.

In public catastrophes, and in long disruptions of the normal order, whatever it might be, there is always an increase, a sublimation of virtue. At the same time, however, there usually never fails to be a general increase in crime.
And this, too, was plain to see.
In the overall chaos and the collapse of law and order, scoundrels spared by and unafraid of the plague found new opportunities for criminal activity and new assurances of impunity.
Indeed, responsibility for law and order fell into the hands of the very worst of them.
Work as monatti and apparitori was not generally suitable for anyone other than men whose love of theft and debauchery outweighed any innate revulsion or fear of infection.

Their superiors, the commissioners, assigned jobs, prescribed strict rules, and meted out harsh penalties. Both the monatti and the commissioners served under magistrates and nobles delegated to every neighborhood, who were authorized to take summary action every time public order was needed.

This system worked effectively for a while, but with commissioners dying by the day, abandoning the city, or losing their minds, almost no one was left to restrain the monatti, giving them virtually free rein.

They entered homes as if they owned them, as enemies. They robbed and harassed the unfortunate plague victims who fell into their grips, and placed their vile, infectious hands on healthy children, parents, husbands, and wives, threatening to haul them off to the lazaretto unless they or someone else paid a ransom.
Other times they would demand payment for their services, refusing to remove putrefying bodies unless they received a hefty sum.

Tadino confirms (102) that the monatti and apparitori deliberately let infected clothing fall off the carts, in order to spread the plague and keep it going, since it had become a source of income, power, and revelry for them (though between the carelessness of some writers and the treachery of the monatti, it’s hard to know who to believe).
Some wretches pretended to be monatti by tying a bell around one ankle, the identification traditionally used to warn of their approach. They would enter houses and wreak havoc.
Thieves would ransack empty houses, or the homes of the listless or dying, and plunder freely, while policemen would break into others and do the same, or worse.
As crime grew, so did madness. All the more or less prevailing distortions gained extraordinary power from the general distress and hysteria, with quicker and more widespread effects.
On the whole they reinforced and heightened that special fear of unguents, a fear which, as we have seen, inspired a crime of a different sort.

People were more obsessed and tormented by that imaginary peril than the real and present danger. As Ripamonti writes, “While the whole city was turned into a giant cemetery by the corpses scattered about or piled up, always before your eyes, always between your feet, there was something uglier, more deadly, in those furious recriminations, in those unhinged, monstrous suspicions…not only was the neighbor, the friend, the guest, to be distrusted, but even those names, those bonds of human charity—husband and wife, father and son, brother and brother—became words of terror. And—how awful and shameful to say!—the family meal, the nuptial bed—were feared as traps, as places that might conceal the pestilential venom.”
The imaginary dimensions and bizarre nature of the alleged plot clouded all judgment and undermined the very foundations of mutual trust.

At first people thought the supposed anointers were simply driven by ambition and greed. Then, they imagined, they believed, that these criminals took diabolical delight in spreading the plague, a temptation that overpowered their will.
The ravings of the sick, accusing themselves of behavior they had feared from others, were treated as truth, and made it possible to believe anything about anyone.

More convincing than their words were their actions, if delirious plague victims really did the things they imagined the anointers had done. This seems very likely and it helps explain both public opinion and many writers’ claims.

Thus, in the long grim period of the witch trials, the defendants’ confessions (which were not always extorted) played no small part in promoting and supporting the prevailing opinion since, when an opinion prevails among too many and for too long, it ultimately expresses itself in every way, knocking on every door, attempting every method of persuasion. And it is hard for all or many to continue believing that something strange is being done without someone coming forward who believes he has done it.
Among the stories that the delirium about unguents led people to believe, there is one that deserves mention because of the credibility it gained and the circulation it enjoyed.

The tale was told—though not everyone told it in exactly the same way (too singular a privilege for tall tales), but almost—that on a certain day, a certain man saw a six-horse carriage pull up to the Duomo. Inside, along with the other passengers, there was a grand personage with a dark and fiery face, blazing eyes, bristling hair, and menacing lips.
As the man stood and stared, the carriage came to a halt and the coachman invited him to get in.

The man did not dare to say no. After rambling through the city, the party descended from the carriage before a palace whereupon the man, on entering, discovered delights and horrors, deserts and gardens, caverns and halls.

He came upon an assembly of seated ghosts in one room who showed him giant chests filled with money, and told him that he could take as much as he liked, on the condition that he also accept a jar of the unguent, which he should spatter around the city.
When he refused, in the blink of an eye he found himself back where his journey had begun.
This story—widely believed by the common people and, according to Ripamonti, insufficiently derided by men of influence—circulated throughout Italy and beyond.

In Germany it was even published. The Archbishop-Elector of Mainz wrote to Cardinal Federigo asking him if he should believe the amazing stories coming from Milan. The Cardinal replied that they were a hallucination.
The hallucinations of the learned were of equal value, if not of entirely equal nature, and equally damaging in their effects.

Most of the learned believed that a comet which had appeared in the year 1628, as well as the alignment of Saturn and Jupiter, were evil omens and causes of the troubles. Tadino writes, “So clearly did the aforementioned conjunction influence the year 1630 that everyone could see it. Mortales parat morbos, miranda videntur—Prepare for deadly diseases, wondrous things will be seen.” This prediction, taken, they said, from a book titled Specchio degli almanacchi perfetti, published in Turin in 1623, was on everyone’s lips.
Another comet, which appeared in June of the same year as the plague, was interpreted as yet another omen, or even, as clear proof of the unguents.

The learned pored over books for examples of what they called “man-made” plague, and unfortunately they found many: They quoted from Livy, Tacitus, Cassius Dio, even Homer and Ovid, and the many other ancients who described similar occurrences. There was an even greater abundance of moderns.

They quoted a hundred other authors who wrote scholarly treatises or spoke incidentally about poisons, sorcery, unguents, powders: Cesalpino, Cardano, Grevin, Salio, Paré, Schenck, Zacchia, and, finally, the deadly Delrio. If an author’s fame were proportionate to the sum of good and evil caused by his works, Martin Delrio would be one of the most famous. For Delrio’s writings cost the lives of more men than the feats of any conquistador. The same Delrio whose Disquisitiones magicae (a summary up to his own times of man’s every delusion on the subject) had become the most indisputable authority, providing the justification and driving force behind incessant, horrific, and legal carnage for more than a century.

The learned borrowed whatever delusions of the common people suited their own ideas. And the commoners borrowed whatever they could understand, and as best as they could understand, from the hallucinations of the learned. And from the combination of the two, an enormous tangle of public insanity was formed.
Even more astonishing was the behavior of the doctors.

I am referring to the doctors who had believed in the plague from the beginning. I am referring in particular to Tadino, who had warned of it, seen it arrive, and kept his eye, so to speak, on its progress. He had said and preached that it was the plague, that it was spread through human contact, and that the whole country would be infected unless protective measures were taken. But now, he, too, began to derive conclusive proof of poisonous, harmful unguents from these same symptoms. This is the same man who had remarked that delirium was a side effect of the disease after the second person in Milan, Carlo Colonna, died of the plague. It was shocking to see him cite the following incidents as proof of unguents and a diabolic plot: Two witnesses gave a deposition that people had come into their sick friend’s room one night to show him the cure and offer him money if he was willing to anoint the houses in his neighborhood. When he refused, they vanished, and in their place was a wolf under the bed and three big cats on top, “which would remain there until daybreak” (123–124).

If only one person had told this story, he would be considered eccentric, and not worth mentioning. But many and indeed almost everyone repeated it, turning this incident into a metaphor for the human spirit, and providing us with the opportunity to see how an orderly and reasonable series of ideas can be thrown into disarray by another series of ideas that crosses its path.
Especially coming from a man like Tadino, one of the most reputable men of his time.
Two illustrious, much-admired writers claim that Cardinal Federigo doubted the existence of unguents.

We wish we could more fully praise his glorious and loving memory, and depict the good priest, here and in many other respects, as superior to most of his contemporaries. But we are forced to see even a mind as noble as his fall victim to the sway of public opinion.

We have seen, at least in the pages of Ripamonti, that he truly was doubtful at first. Throughout the pestilence, he attributed much of this opinion to credulousness, ignorance, fear, and the desire to atone for taking so long to acknowledge the epidemic and take the necessary precautions. While he thought the rumors about these poisonous unguents were exaggerated, he came to believe that there was also an element of truth.
Among the holdings of the Ambrosian Library, there is a short work about the plague, written in his hand, which alludes to his change of heart. In one passage he states it quite explicitly.

“It was the common opinion,” he writes, more or less, “that these unguents were mixed in various places, and that there were many different ways to spread them: some of which appear true, some fabricated.”

(His exact words were: “Unguenta uero haec aiebant componi conficique multifariam, fraudisque uias fuisse complures; quarum sane fraudum, et artium aliis quidem assentimur, alias uero fictas fuisse comentitiasque arbitramur.”)

There were still some, however, who believed right to the end of the plague, even to the end of their lives, that the unguents were pure fantasy. We know this not from them, since no one was brave enough to express in public an opinion that was so contrary to public opinion. We know it from writers who derided, criticized, or rejected the belief in unguents, saying that it was the prejudice of some, and though they did not dare openly dispute it, their objections still persisted. We also know it from people who had the story handed down to them.

“I have come across people in Milan,” writes the good Muratori in the aforementioned book, “who had received reliable reports from their ancestors and were not persuaded that these poisonous unguents existed.”
We can see that there was a clandestine outlet for the truth, a family secret: Good sense did indeed exist, but it stayed hidden for fear of common sense.
There were fewer magistrates every day. They were increasingly dismayed and confused, and dedicated what little resolve they could muster to hunting down the anointers.

Among the documents of the plague in the San Fedele archive, there is a letter (with no attachments) in which the Grand Chancellor informs the Governor, in all seriousness and with great urgency, that he has received reports of poison being made in the country home of the brothers Girolamo and Giulio Monti, Milanese gentlemen. They were producing such large quantities that they had employed forty men en este exercicio, with the assistance of four horsemen from Brescia, who had the ingredients shipped from the Venetian Republic para la fabrica del veneno.

He went on to say that, with the utmost secrecy, he had already made the necessary arrangements to send in the Mayor of Milan and the Auditor of the Tribunal of Health with thirty cavalrymen. But unfortunately one of the brothers had been tipped off in time to escape with the evidence of the crime—probably by his friend the Auditor, who invented excuses to delay the expedition. Nevertheless the Mayor departed with the soldiers to reconocer la casa, y a ver si hallará algunos vestigios (search the house and see if they couldn’t find some traces), collect information, and arrest anyone who was implicated.
The whole affair must have come to nothing, since contemporary accounts of the suspicions hanging over the two gentlemen do not cite any proof.
Unfortunately, on another occasion, the authorities were convinced that they did indeed have proof.
The trials that followed as a result were certainly not the first of their kind. Nor can they be considered a rarity in the history of jurisprudence.

Leaving aside antiquity and limiting ourselves to a period closer to the time we are examining, I can name Palermo, in 1526; Geneva, in 1530, then again in 1545, still later in 1574; Casale Monferrato, in 1536; Padua, in 1555; and Turin, in 1599 and again in 1630. In that same year, greater or smaller numbers of unhappy souls were put on trial and sentenced to the most atrocious tortures, convicted of having spread the plague with powders, unguents, sorcery, or a combination of all three.

The most well known, and perhaps easiest to analyze, is the so-called unguents of Milan case, because the survival of detailed documentation from this period allows greater opportunities for analysis.

Although a writer whom I have just praised also discussed this case, he was aiming not so much to record the history, as to use it in support of greater and more immediate study, so I felt this story could be material for a new work.
But it is not a matter that can be settled in few words, and this is not the place to treat it at the length it deserves.
Not to mention that the reader might not necessarily care to know the rest of our story after dwelling on these cases.
So we will set aside this particular story and the analysis of these documents for another piece of writing, and finally return to our characters, whom we shall not abandon again until the end.
